Authors: Schubert, D., LaCorbiere, M.
Title: Isolation of a cell-surface receptor for chick neural retina adherons
Affiliations: The Salk Institute, San Diego, CA 92138, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, D., The Salk Institute, San Diego, CA 92138, United States; LaCorbiere, M., The Salk Institute, San Diego, CA 92138, United States
Abstract: Embryonic chick neural retina cells release glycoprotein complexes, termed adherons, into their culture medium. When adsorbed onto the surface of petri dishes, neural retina adherons increase the initial rate of neural retina cell adhesion. In solution they increase the rate of cell-cell aggregation. Cell-cell and adheron-cell adhesions of cultured retina cells are selectively inhibited by heparan-sulfate glycosaminoglycan, but not by chondroitin sulfate or hyaluronic acid, suggesting that a heparan-sulfate proteoglycan may be involved in the adhesion process. We isolated a heparan-sulfate proteoglycan from the growth-conditioned medium of neural retina cells, and prepared an antiserum against it. Monovalent Fab' fragments of these antibodies completely inhibited cell-adheron adhesion, and partially blocked spontaneous cell-cell aggregation. An antigenically and structurally similar heparan-sulfate proteoglycan was isolated from the cell surface. This proteoglycan bound directly to adherons, and when absorbed to plastic, stimulated cell-substratum adhesion. These data suggest that a heparan-sulfate proteoglycan on the surface of chick neural retina cells acted as a receptor for adhesion-mediating glycoprotein complexes (adherons).

Authors: Cole, G.J., Schubert, D., Glaser, L.
Title: Cell-substratum adhesion in chick neural retina depends upon protein-heparan sulfate interactions
Affiliations: Department of Biological Chemistry, Division of Biology and Biomedical Sciences, Washington University School of Medicine, St. Louis, MO 63110, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cole, G.J., Department of Biological Chemistry, Division of Biology and Biomedical Sciences, Washington University School of Medicine, St. Louis, MO 63110, United States; Schubert, D., Department of Biological Chemistry, Division of Biology and Biomedical Sciences, Washington University School of Medicine, St. Louis, MO 63110, United States; Glaser, L., Department of Biological Chemistry, Division of Biology and Biomedical Sciences, Washington University School of Medicine, St. Louis, MO 63110, United States
Abstract: Embryonic chick neural retina cells in culture release complexes of proteins and glycosaminogens, termed adherons, which stimulate cell-substratum adhesion when adsorbed to nonadhesive surfaces. Two distinct retinal cell surface macromolecules, a 170,000-mol-wt glycoprotein and a heparin sulfate proteoglycan, are components of adherons that can independently promote adhesion when coated on inert surfaces. The 170,000-mol-wt polypeptide contains a heparin-binding domain, as indicated by its retention on heparin-agarose columns and its ability to bind [3H]heparin in solutions. The attachment of embryonic chick retinal cells to the 170,000-mol-wt protein also depends upon interactions between the protein and the heparin sulfate proteoglycan, since heparin sulfate in solution disrupts adhesion of chick neural retina cells to glass surfaces coated with the 170,000-mol-wt protein. This adhesion is not impaired by chondroitin sulfate or hyaluronic acid, which indicates that inhibition by heparan sulfate is specific. Polyclonal antisera directed against the cell surface heparan sulfate proteoglycan also inhibit attachment of retinal cells to the 170,000-mol-wt protein, which suggests that cell-adheron binding is mediated in parts by interactions between cell surface heparin sulfate proteoglycan and 170,000-mol-wt protein contained in the adheron particles. Previous studies have indicated that this type of cell-substratum adhesion is tissue-specific since retina cells do not attach to muscle adherons (Schubert D., M. LaCorbiere, F.G. Klier, and C. Birdwell, 1983, J. Cell Biol. 96:990-998).

Authors: Traynor, A.E., Schubert, D.
Title: Phospholipases elevate cyclic AMP levels and promote neurite extension in a clonal nerve cell line.
Authors with affiliations: Traynor, A.E.; Schubert, D.
Abstract: Phospholipases A2 and C increase choline acetyltransferase (CAT) activity and promote neurite extension in PC12 cells. Since these phospholipases also elevate intracellular cyclic AMP, they probably stimulate CAT and neurite outgrowth through their ability to increase cyclic AMP levels. Other possible modes of action of phospholipases such as the release of arachidonic acid or the production of lysolipids are less likely to play a role in this system.

Authors: Schubert, D., LaCorbiere, M.
Title: Properties of extracellular adhesion-mediating particles in myoblast clone and its adhesion-deficient variant
Affiliations: Salk Inst., San Diego, CA 92138, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, D., Salk Inst., San Diego, CA 92138, United States; LaCorbiere, M., Salk Inst., San Diego, CA 92138, United States
Abstract: Both the skeletal muscle myoblast cell line L6 and an adhesion-deficient variant of L6 released glycoprotein complexes, termed adherons, into their culture medium. The adherons from the variant, M3A, differed from those of L6 in a number of properties. M3A adherons were much less effective in promoting the cell-substratum and cell-cell adhesion of myoblasts than L6 particles. The adherons from the two cell lines also differed in their relative sedimentation velocities in sucrose gradients and had different chemical compositions. The M3A particle lacked chondroitin and contained relatively less collagen and fibronectin than the L6 adheron. Both L6 and M3A particles adhered to plastic surfaces and cells equally well in the absence of calcium ions. Neither cell-cell adhesion nor particle aggregation occurred in calcium-free medium. However, in the presence of calcium, the L6 adherons aggregated completely and M3A particles aggregated poorly. These data suggest that at least two sets of interactions are required for adheron-mediated adhesion: a calcium-independent binding of the adheron to the cell, and a calcium-dependent interaction between particles that is directly responsible for adhesion. The M3A variant is blocked at the calcium-dependent step, resulting in an adhesion deficiency.

Authors: Traynor, A.E., Schubert, D., Allen, W.R.
Title: Alterations of lipid metabolism in response to nerve growth factor
Affiliations: Salk Inst., San Diego, CA 92138, United States
Authors with affiliations: Traynor, A.E., Salk Inst., San Diego, CA 92138, United States; Schubert, D., Salk Inst., San Diego, CA 92138, United States; Allen, W.R., Salk Inst., San Diego, CA 92138, United States
Abstract: In response to nerve growth factor (NGF), clonal pheochromocytoma cells flatten and extend neurites capable of making functional synapses. Although no significant changes in overall phospholipid composition occur in the presence of NGF, there is increased incorporation of 32PO4 into phosphatidylinositol and phosphatidic acid within 10 min after the addition of NGF. NGF stimulates the incorporation of 32PO4 into other lipids, such as phosphatidylcholine, to a lesser extent. The kinetics of the NGF-induced phosphatidylinositol responses are different when the cells are in suspension from when they are attached to culture dishes. These changes in phospholipid metabolism are discussed with respect to their role in NGF-induced nerve differentiation.

Authors: LaCorbiere, M., Schubert, D.
Title: The role of cAMP in the induction of ornithine decarboxylase by nerve and epidermal growth factors
Affiliations: Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif., United States
Authors with affiliations: LaCorbiere, M., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif., United States; Schubert, D., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif., United States
Abstract: Nerve growth factor (NGF), epidermal growth factor (EGF), adenosine 3',5'-cyclic monophosphate (cAMP), and cholera toxin all increase the specific activity of ornithine decarboxylase (ODC) in the PC12 nerve-like cell line. A phosphodiesterase inhibitor augments the effect of NGF on the induction of ODC in these cells, while it is only additive with the EGF response. These data suggest that cAMP has an intermediary role in the induction of ODC by NGF and that cAMP is not involved in the EGF response.

Authors: Napias, C., Olsen, R.W., Schubert, D.
Title: GABA and picrotoxinin receptors in clonal nerve cells [16]
Affiliations: Division of Biomedical Sciences, Department of Biochemistry, University of California, Riverside, CA 92521, United States; Department of Neurobiology, Salk Institute for Biological Studies, PO Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Napias, C., Division of Biomedical Sciences, Department of Biochemistry, University of California, Riverside, CA 92521, United States; Olsen, R.W., Division of Biomedical Sciences, Department of Biochemistry, University of California, Riverside, CA 92521, United States; Schubert, D., Department of Neurobiology, Salk Institute for Biological Studies, PO Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States
Abstract: γAminobutyric acid (GABA) is a neurotransmitter which seems to mediate inhibitory synaptic transmission in many regions of the central nervous system (CNS) of vertebrates and invertebrates1. GABA has been shown to act by increasing membrane chloride permeability in invertebrate muscle 2,3, and a similar mechanism has been suggested for the vertebrate CNS4. The response to GABA is inhibited noncompetitively by the convulsant picrotoxinin1-5. Binding sites for radioactive GAB A 6-8 and picrotoxinin9-11 (the active component of picrotoxin) have been described in homogenates of invertebrate muscle and mammalian CNS; these binding sites show many properties expected of postsynaptic membrane macromolecules involved in the receptor-ionophore function of GABA. Nevertheless, unambiguous correlation between biochemical assays and in vivo function is difficult to obtain, especially in heterogeneous tissue such as mammalian CNS. One approach to this problem involves cloned cell lines of neuronal origin which retain in culture the differentiated function to be studied (see, for example, ref. 12). Certain cell lines cloned from rat 13 and mouse14 nervous system possess neuronal properties such as electrical excitability, neurotransmitter synthetic enzymes 12, neurotransmitter uptake15,16, binding of defined ligands to their appropriate neurotransmitter receptors12,17,18, and receptor-coupled responses to neurotransmitters17,19,20. Several cell lines of apparent glial origin have also been described13,21,22. To determine whether binding sites for GABA and picrotoxinin are localised to nerve cells, a variety of clonal cell lines were assayed for their ability to bind those ligands. We report here the presence of GABA and picrotoxinin binding sites with receptor-like properties in several clonal nerve cell lines obtained from the rat CNS, and the absence of such binding sites in many other cell lines of non-neuronal origin. © 1980 Nature Publishing Group.

Authors: Schubert, D., LaCorbiere, M., Klier, F.G., Steinbach, J.H.
Title: The modulation of neurotransmitter synthesis by steroid hormones and insulin
Affiliations: Neurobiology Department, The Salk Institute, P.O. Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, D., Neurobiology Department, The Salk Institute, P.O. Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States; LaCorbiere, M., Neurobiology Department, The Salk Institute, P.O. Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States; Klier, F.G., Neurobiology Department, The Salk Institute, P.O. Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States; Steinbach, J.H., Neurobiology Department, The Salk Institute, P.O. Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States
Abstract: Glucocorticoids stimulate tyrosine hydroxylase activity and catecholamine synthesis, while markedly inhibiting acetycholine synthesis and storage in a clone of sympathetic nerve-like cells. Nerve growth factor enhances the effect of glucocorticoids on tyrosine hydroxylase. The steroid effect is specific for glucocorticoids, since 11-desoxycortisol, testosterone, and estradiol-17β do not reproduce the effects of hydrocortisone and dexamethasone. Concomitant with the shift in neurotransmitter synthesis, there is an increase in the mean diameter of intracellular dense core vesicles. In contrast to glucocorticoids, insulin increases the specific activity of choline acetylttransferase through the interaction with typical insulin receptors. Insulin does not, however, alter the morphology of the cells, nor does it block the morphological response of the cells to nerve growth factor. © 1980.

Authors: Steinbach, J.H., Schubert, D., Eldridge, L.
Title: Changes in cat muscle contractile proteins after prolonged muscle inactivity
Affiliations: Neurobiology Department, The Salk Institute, P.O. Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States; Department of Physiology, School of Medicine, University of California, Los Angeles, CA 90024, United States
Authors with affiliations: Steinbach, J.H., Neurobiology Department, The Salk Institute, P.O. Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States, Department of Physiology, School of Medicine, University of California, Los Angeles, CA 90024, United States; Eldridge, L., Neurobiology Department, The Salk Institute, P.O. Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States, Department of Physiology, School of Medicine, University of California, Los Angeles, CA 90024, United States
Abstract: Contractile proteins in cat hind limb muscles were studied to examine the possibility that prolonged inactivity of innervated skeletal muscle results in changes in the complement of contractile proteins synthesized by fast- or slow-twich muscles. Myosin light chains and tropomyosins from cat fast- and slow-twitch skeletal muscles were identified in two-dimensional gel electrophoretic patterns. The protein complement synthesized by initially slow-twitch muscle became more similar to that of fast-twitch after long periods (2 to 3 years) of surgically produced inactivity. In some animals slow-twitch forms of myosin light chains and tropomyosins were not seen in normally slow-twitch muscles. These results are in agreement with data obtained in other studies of contractile and biochemical properties of the inactivated muscles. © 1980.

Authors: Lennon, V.A., Peterson, S., Schubert, D.
Title: Neurectoderm markers retained in phenotypical skeletal muscle cells arising from a glial cell line [23]
Affiliations: Neuroimmunology Laboratory, Departments of Neurology and Immunology, Mayo Clinic and Medical School, Rochester, MN 55901, United States; Neurobiology Laboratory, Salk Institute for Biological Studies, San Diego, CA 92112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lennon, V.A., Neuroimmunology Laboratory, Departments of Neurology and Immunology, Mayo Clinic and Medical School, Rochester, MN 55901, United States; Peterson, S., Neuroimmunology Laboratory, Departments of Neurology and Immunology, Mayo Clinic and Medical School, Rochester, MN 55901, United States; Schubert, D., Neurobiology Laboratory, Salk Institute for Biological Studies, San Diego, CA 92112, United States
Abstract: Differentiation in vitro of striated muscle from apparently non-muscle precursor cells has been reported in thymus reticulum1, a fibroblast-like mouse embryo line2 and in a neuronelike cell line derived from a rat brain tumour3. Also Tomozawa and Sueko reported the differentiation of a peripheral neurotumour clonal stem cell line into separate neuronal and glial cell types4. We report here the reproducible and stable phenotypic change of a well characterised rat glial cell line, B9 (refs 5-;7), into multinucleate contractile skeletal muscle. The B9 line was derived from a nitrosoethylurea-induced brain tumour, contains S-100 and 14-3-2 proteins, is electrically non-excitable 5 and has a putative glial-specific surface antigen, G2 (ref. 6). It has been phenotypically stable in its laboratory of origin at Salk Institute since 1973. After being transported to the Mayo Clinic in Minnesota the cells began to change from cuboidal to elongate shape, fuse into contractile multinucleate fibres and express nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (AChR) on their plasma membranes. Striated myofibrils appeared in their cytoplasm. The first sign of mesectodermal differentiation in B9 was the transitory appearance on its surface of Thy-1 which, in the rat, is a marker of thymocytes8, certain brain cell lines7, immature skeletal muscle9,10, mammary myoepithelial lines11 and fibro-blasts12. This antigen was not detected in previous studies at Salk Institute7. The inductive influence is not yet known. We propose that transformation of a neurectodermal line into muscle may be evidence of the capacity of mammalian neurectoderm to give rise to skeletal tissues. The concept that skeletal muscle in different anatomical regions might have different embryonic origins could be relevant to the distribution of muscles affected by certain diseases in man. © 1979 Nature Publishing Group.

Authors: Garrels, J.I., Schubert, D.
Title: Modulation of protein synthesis by nerve growth factor
Affiliations: Neurobiol. Lab., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Garrels, J.I., Neurobiol. Lab., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States; Schubert, D., Neurobiol. Lab., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States
Abstract: The effects of nerve growth factor (NGF) and two analogs of cAMP have been studied in the PC12 line of rat pheochromocytoma cells. We have used two-dimensional gel electrophoresis to detect more than 800 proteins from control and NGF-treated cells. Of these proteins, none were qualitatively repressed in response to NGF, and no new proteins appeared after NGF treatment. Visual inspection of the gels showed that approximately 5% of the proteins were detectably increased or decreased in rate of synthesis by NGF, and each of these changes was mimicked by both cAMP analogs. The two-dimensional gel data were further analyzed by a computerized scanning system. This analysis has revealed many significant changes that are smaller than those detected by eye. Approximately 25 to 30% of the proteins analyzed were found to be altered in rate of synthesis by 30% or more. Statistical analysis has shown that the response to NGF and the response to dibutyryl cAMP are highly correlated, even down to changes as small as 30%. No proteins were found to be significantly altered by both dibutyryl cAMP and 8-bromo cAMP, but not by NGF. These results show that NGF causes only quantitative modulations of protein synthesis in PC12 cells, and these dta strongly suggest that the response of PC12 cells to NGF is mediated by cAMP.

Authors: Schubert, D.
Title: Insulin-induced cell-substratum adhesion
Affiliations: Neurobiology Laboratory, The Salk Institute, San Diego, CA 92112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, D., Neurobiology Laboratory, The Salk Institute, San Diego, CA 92112, United States
Abstract: The effect of insulin on cell-substratum adhesion was examined using clonal cell lines from the nervous system, myoblasts, and lymphoid cells. Insulin increases adhesion in nerve cells, myoblasts, and lymphomas, but not in the glial and myeloma cell lines examined. In a myoblast variant, M3A, the reaction is specific for insulin and its analogues, and is energy and temperature dependent. © 1979.

Authors: Schubert, D.
Title: Early events after the interaction of NGF with sympathetic nerve cells
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, D.
Abstract: Nerve growth factor (NGF) is a substance which plays an important role in the differentiation, maintenance, and control of direction of growth of sympathetic neurones. In this article, David Schubert describes experiments using a clonal tissue culture line of sympathetic ganglion-like cells and suggests that cAMP, calcium ion fluxes, and increased cell-substratum adhesion are involved in NGF-induced neurite extension. © 1979.

Authors: Schubert, D., LaCorbiere, M., Whitlock, C., Stallcup, W.
Title: Alterations in the surface properties of cells responsive to nerve growth factor
Affiliations: Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, D., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States; LaCorbiere, M., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States; Whitlock, C., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States; Stallcup, W., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States
Abstract: An initial effect of nerve growth factor on a responsive nerve cell line is to increase intracellular cyclic AMP, which in turn leads to a mobilisation of calcium ions. These events are correlated with structural changes in the plasma membrane, increased cell-substratum adhesion, and neurite outgrowth.

Authors: Patrick, J., Heinemann, S., Schubert, D.
Title: Biology of cultured nerve and muscle.
Authors with affiliations: Patrick, J.; Heinemann, S.; Schubert, D.
Abstract: Cells from the nervous system can be grown in culture and exhibit many of the biophysical, biochemical, and morphological properties found in vivo. They can be induced to differentiate in culture and perform some of the interactions that occur in the nervous system, including synaptogenesis. A number of important questions relating to nervous system development and function have been approached in culture in ways that cannot be done in vivo. The use of clonal cell lines should lead to rapid progress in the analysis of the nervous system at the chemical level.

Authors: Schubert, D., Whitlock, C.
Title: Alteration of cellular adhesion by nerve growth factor
Source title: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
Affiliations: Neurobiol. Lab., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, D., Neurobiol. Lab., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States; Whitlock, C., Neurobiol. Lab., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States
Abstract: Nerve growth factor increases the initial rates of cell-substratum and cell-cell adhesion of sympathetic nerve cell clone PC12. It also stimulates adenosine 3':5'-cyclic monophosphate accumulation in the cells, and exogenous adenosine 3':5'-cyclic monophosphate increases cell-substratum adhesion. NGF-stimulated adhesion is energy dependent and cold-sensitive and does not require do novo protein synthesis. It is probably mediated by an effect of adenosine 3':5'-cyclic monophosphate on the plasma membrane. Stimulation of cellular adhesion may the first step in NGF-initiated neurite outgrowth by sympathetic nerve cells.

Authors: Schubert, D., Klier, F.G.
Title: Storage and release of acetylcholine by a clonal cell line
Source title: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
Affiliations: Neurobiol. Lab., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, D., Neurobiol. Lab., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States; Klier, F.G., Neurobiol. Lab., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States
Abstract: The nerve cell line PC12, in its morphologically undifferentiated state, synthesizes, stores, and secretes catecholamines and acetylcholine. At least 60% of the basal level of neurotransmitter release is due to a calcium-dependent mechanism, and the rate of secretion is enhanced by increasing external potassium. A minimum of 80% of the intracellular acetylcholine and catecholamines are stored in particulate structures. The storage site for acetylcholine is dense core vesicles that can be distinguished from those containing catecholamines on the basis of vesicle density on sucrose gradients, vesicle size, and reserpine sensitivity. These results are discussed in relation to what are thought to be the early stages of synapse formation in cell culture.

Authors: Schubert, D., Heinemann, S., Kidokoro, Y.
Title: Cholinergic metabolism and synapse formation by a rat nerve cell line
Source title: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
Affiliations: Neurobiol. Lab., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, D., Neurobiol. Lab., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States; Heinemann, S., Neurobiol. Lab., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States; Kidokoro, Y., Neurobiol. Lab., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States
Abstract: The PC12 clone of a rat pheochromocytoma is able to synthesize acetylcholine. The amount of acetylcholine synthesized, and the specific activity of choline O-acetyltransferase (acetyl-CoA:choline O-acetyltransferase) varies as a function of the culture growth curve and is dependent on cell density. The specific activity of choline acetyltransferase is increased by nerve growth factor, growth-conditioned medium from a variety of cell types, and adenosine 3':5'-monophosphate. Finally, the PC12 cell line is able to form cholinergic synapses with a clonal cell line of skeletal muscle origin.

Affiliations: Department of Neurobiology, The Salk Institute, San Diego, CA 92112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, D., Department of Neurobiology, The Salk Institute, San Diego, CA 92112, United States
Abstract: A large number of clonal cell lines were examined for the deposition of proteins (substrate attached material, SAM) on the substratum of culture dishes. Of the many cell types examined, only nerve, muscle, and glia synthesized SAM containing a predominant species of protein with an apparent molecular weight of 55,000. This 55,000 molecular weight protein is distinguishable from actin, tubulin, and collagen. © 1977.

Authors: Klier, F.G., Schubert, D., Heinemann, S.
Title: The ultrastructural differentiation of the clonal myogenic cell line L6 in normal and high K+ medium
Affiliations: Neurobiology Laboratory, The Salk Institute, P.O. Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Klier, F.G., Neurobiology Laboratory, The Salk Institute, P.O. Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States; Schubert, D., Neurobiology Laboratory, The Salk Institute, P.O. Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States; Heinemann, S., Neurobiology Laboratory, The Salk Institute, P.O. Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States
Abstract: Cells of the clonal myogenic line L6 were examined electron microscopically at successive stages of growth. L6 cells are developmentally similar to those of chick and rat primary skeletal muscle cultures and skeletal muscle in vivo, with respect to myofibrillogenesis and sarcomere organization. However, the sarcoplasmic reticulum and T systems of L6 myotubes are not as well differentiated as those of primary muscle cultures and adult skeletal muscle. Finally, L6 myotubes show precocious sarcomere differentiation when cultured in medium containing 25 mM potassium. © 1977.

Authors: Schubert, D., Lacorbiere, M., Watson, J.
Title: Growth regulation of cells grown in suspension culture
Affiliations: Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, D., Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States; Lacorbiere, M., Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States; Watson, J., Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States
Abstract: Various aspects of a cell's growth cycle can be manipulated in tissue culture. For example, the initiation of DNA synthesis and, in some cases, culture growth, can be enhanced by serum and platelet components, polypeptides purified from growth conditioned medium and urine, insulin, corticosteroids, prostaglandins, cyclic nucleotides and proteolytic enzymes. In addition, at least three purified proteins can initiate DNA synthesis in fibroblast like cells - nerve growth factor, epidermal growth factor and fibroblast growth factor. Disturbance of the culture medium directly over the cultured cells also induces DNA synthesis. Fibroblast like cells have been used in most of these studies, and they grow tightly associated with the culture dish and are strongly anchorage dependent for division. Given the strong anchorage dependence of the test cells, two alternatives could account for the induction of DNA synthesis and growth by the diversity of conditions and 'factors' outlined above. The first would ascribe the effects of these compounds to interactions on the cell surface with a suitable receptor. These are hormone like interactions, thought to be exemplified by compounds such as insulin and purified growth factors. The second alternative represents interactions which function directly through alterations of cell anchorage. For example, the growth stimulating effects of the proteases are presumably affected by modification of the cell substratum (anchorage) interaction. To distinguish between these two alternatives, it should be sufficient to assay the effects of serum and a purified growth factor on the initiation of DNA synthesis in an anchorage dependent cell line, and on a variant which grows in suspension culture. If serum and the growth factor were equally effective in both cell lines, then a disturbance in anchorage could not account for the mitogenic activity, ruling out the second alternative. The first, hormone like, mechanism, however, would be excluded if the growth factor was unable to induce DNA synthesis in the cells grown in suspension. The experiments described support this latter possibility by showing that fibroblast growth factor does not affect the growth of myoblast cells grown in suspension culture.

Authors: Schubert, D., Tarikas, H., LaCorbiere, M.
Title: Neurotransmitter regulation of adenosine 3',5' monophosphate in clonal nerve, glia, and muscle cell lines
Affiliations: Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, D., Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States; Tarikas, H., Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States; LaCorbiere, M., Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States
Abstract: Norepinephrine increases the intracellular level of adenosine 3',5' monophosphate (cyclic AMP) in clonal cell lines of nerve, glia, smooth muscle, and skeletal muscle. The largest response is in skeletal muscle, where the cyclic nucleotide concentration is elevated more than 500 fold. Glia and muscle cells, but not nerve cells, respond to dopamine with increased cyclic AMP accumulation. This response appears to be mediated through a beta adrenoreceptor.

Authors: Schubert, D.
Title: Proteins secreted by clonal cell lines. Changes in metabolism with culture growth
Affiliations: Department of Neurobiology, The Salk Institute, San Diego, CA 92112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, D., Department of Neurobiology, The Salk Institute, San Diego, CA 92112, United States
Abstract: Clonal cell lines release glycoproteins into their culture medium, some of which appear to be derived from the outer cell surface. These proteins do not originate from lysed cells, nor do they comigrate on SDS acrylamide gels with the proteins of substrate attached material. When the proteins released from exponentially dividing cells are compared with those from stationary phase cells, marked differences are found. In addition, the proteins released from normal stationary cells differ from those precociously growth arrested with db-cAMP or by serum deprivation. The spectrum of proteins released by the serum-deprived cells is more like that of normal stationary phase cells than db-cAMP-inhibited cells. © 1976.

Authors: Schubert, D., Carlisle, W., Look, C.
Title: Putative neurotransmitters in clonal cell lines
Affiliations: Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., La Jolla, Calif. 92112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, D., Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., La Jolla, Calif. 92112, United States; Carlisle, W., Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., La Jolla, Calif. 92112, United States; Look, C., Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., La Jolla, Calif. 92112, United States
Abstract: The authors used the rat nerve cell lines B35, B50, B65, B103 and B104, and the rat putative glial cell lines B11, B15, B23, B28, B49, B82, B90, B92 and B108, and two other lines of glial origin, C6 and RN2. Additional clonal cell lines examined were: smooth muscles BC3H1 and A10; skeletal muscle L6; plasmacytoma C1 and lymphomas S1A and S49; neuroblastoma clones C1 and N18; melanomas B78 and B559; hepatoma H35; growth hormone and prolactin producing pituitary cells GH3; adrenal cortical line Y1; and the fibroblast cell line 3T3. All cells were grown in modified Eagle's MEM containing 10% fetal calf serum. Early stationary phase cultures, 2 or 3 days after cessation of net cell division, were used exclusively for the determination of free amino acids for cells at this stage of the growth cycle usually express maximum morphological and biochemical differentiation. Cell viability was greater than 95% as measured by the uptake of fluorescein dibutyrate. Cells derived from neuroectoderm contained detectable amounts of GABA and β alanine, although the mesodermally derived muscle and fibroblast cells did not. Thus nerve, glia, melanocytes and neuroblastoma clones had qualitatively similar free amino acid pools distinct from those of muscle and fibroblast cells. It has been shown that nerve and glial cells share a number of additional traits distinct from muscle, such as acetylcholine and catecholamine synthesis, GABA uptake, S100 and 14-3-2 protein synthesis, and a morphological response to cyclic nucleotides. Other cell types, such as those derived from lymphoid tissue, the adrenal cortex and the anterior pituitary, also contained both GABA and β alanine. Thus GABA and β alanine were excluded from most mesodermal tissues as opposed to being uniquely associated with nervous tissue. The apparent exception was the adrenal cortical clone, which is thought to be of mesodermal origin, but contained GABA. The functional similarity between cells of immune and nervous systems has, however, been pointed out repeatedly. In addition, GABA has been found in other tissues in smaller amounts than in the nervous system and may serve a metabolic role. Since no GABA was detected in the culture medium, cells containing GABA probably synthesise it.

Authors: Klier, G., Schubert, D., Heinemann, S.
Title: Ultrastructural changes accompanying the induced differentiation of clonal rat nerve and glia
Affiliations: Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Klier, G., Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States; Schubert, D., Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States; Heinemann, S., Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States
Abstract: Dibutyryladenosine 3 5 monophosphate (DBcAMP) induces ultrastructural transformations in clonal rat nerve and glia. Cells cultured in the presence of DBcAMP contain large numbers of aligned microtubules and microfilaments in their elongated processes, while control cultures without DBcAMP are relatively devoid of these structures. In addition, the cells exposed to DBcAMP contain 2000 Å to 6000 Å vesicles which are not observed in control cells.

Authors: Kidokoro, Y., Heinemann, S., Schubert, D.
Title: Synapse formation and neurotrophic effects on muscle cell lines
Affiliations: Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kidokoro, Y., Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States; Heinemann, S., Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States; Schubert, D., Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States
Abstract: C 1300 neuroblastoma cells were co cultured with myotubes according to methods described by Steinbach and Kidokoro. Phase contrast observations revealed typical contacts which appeared to be structurally different from synapses between spinal cord explants and myotubes. The authors confirmed the findings of Harris that these contacts between neuroblastoma cells and myotubes are functionally inactive. In contrast co cultures of the dorsal part of fetal rat spinal cord and L6 myotubes behaved quite differently. After two weeks of co incubation many myotubes were found to have miniature end plate potentials occurring at rates of 1 to 114 per minute. The cholinergic nature of these potentials was demonstrated by applying d tubocurarine and α neurotoxin. However, KCl failed to enhance the potential frequency. Electron microscopic studies revealed a relatively simple structure. As regards requirements for synapse formation it became evident that α neurotoxin did not prevent synapse formation and that electrical activity in presynaptic nerves is not necessary. Finally the authors tested a great number of cell lines from neurons and muscle systems in vitro. The results of this intensive study concerning biochemical, electrical and ultrastructural aspects should be read in the original article. (Gaillard - Leiden)

Authors: Steinbach, J.H., Schubert, D.
Title: Multiple modes of dibutyryl cyclic AMP-induced process formation by clonal nerve and glial cells
Affiliations: The Neurobiology Department, The Salk Institute, San Diego, CA 92112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Steinbach, J.H., The Neurobiology Department, The Salk Institute, San Diego, CA 92112, United States; Schubert, D., The Neurobiology Department, The Salk Institute, San Diego, CA 92112, United States
Abstract: Exposure of clonal nerve and glial cells to dibutyryl adenosine-3′,5′-monophosphate (db-cAMP) induced processes. These cellular processes were generated either by the extension of a process (growth) or by retraction of parts of an extended cytoplasm (shrinkage). In all cases, these cells from the central nervous system rounded up in response to db-cAMP, rather than spread on the substratum. © 1975.

Authors: Schubert, D.
Title: The uptake of gaba by clonal nerve and glia
Affiliations: Department of Neurobiology, The Salk Institute, P.O. Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, D., Department of Neurobiology, The Salk Institute, P.O. Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States
Abstract: A number of clonal nerve and glial cell lines are able to accumulate exogenous GABA. The ability of the cells to concentrate GABA is dependent upon external calcium, while the uptake process is sodium dependent and temperature sensitive. GABA uptake by the cell lines is specific with respect to analogue inhibition, but this specificity is different from that observed in brain slices. It is, however, similar to that of glia in the rat sensory ganglia. Although clonal muscle cells can concentrate GABA to a limited extent, a number of other differentiated cells cannot. © 1975.

Authors: Schubert, D., Harris, A.J., Devine, C.E., Heinemann, S.
Title: Characterization of a unique muscle cell line
Affiliations: Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., La Jolla, Calif. 92037, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, D., Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., La Jolla, Calif. 92037, United States; Harris, A.J., Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., La Jolla, Calif. 92037, United States; Devine, C.E., Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., La Jolla, Calif. 92037, United States; Heinemann, S., Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., La Jolla, Calif. 92037, United States
Abstract: A clonal cell line derived from a mouse neoplasm is described which shares many properties with smooth muscle. The cells have electrically excitable membranes capable of generating overshooting action potentials, and they contract both spontaneously and with electrical stimulation. They respond to the iontophoretic application of acetylcholine with a depolarizing response, and to norepinephrine with a hyperpolarizing response. Electron microscopy reveals that the cells have a morphology similar in many, but not all, respects to that of smooth muscle cells in vivo. The cells secrete soluble collagen like molecules in addition to several proteins of undefined function. Finally, there is an increase in the specific activities of creatine phosphokinase and myokinase associated with increased cell density and the cessation of cell division.

Authors: Schubert, D.
Title: Induced differentiation of clonal rat nerve and glial cells
Affiliations: Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, D., Dept. Neurobiol., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States
Abstract: The effects of 5 bromodeoxyuridine, serum free medium, and adenosine 3' 5' monophosphate on the morphological differentiation of 5 neuronal and 1 glial cell line are described. 5 bromodeoxyuridine induced cell flattening but not process formation in all 6 cell lines. Serum free medium and dibutyryl adenosine 3' 5' monophosphate reversibly induced neurite formation in the nerve cell lines, but only dibutyryl adenosine 3' 5' monophosphate elicited a comparable response in the glial cell line. Adenosine 3' 5' monophosphate and 8 bromoadenosine 3' 5' monophosphate also induced morphological transformations in these cells. Protein synthesis was not required for the initial morphological changes induced by dibutyryl adenosine 3' 5' monophosphate. Dibutyryl adenosine 3' 5' monophoshate partially protected cells from colchicine induced process retraction, suggesting a functional interaction between these 2 compounds at a site involved in the maintenance of cellular processes.

Abstract: Five neuronal and a large collection of putative glial cell lines from the rat central nervous system have been established in clonal cell culture and partially characterised. Authors: Steinbach, J.H., Harris, A.J., Patrick, J., Schubert, D., Heinemann, S.
Title: Nerve muscle interaction in vitro: Role of acetylcholine
Affiliations: Neurobiol. Dept., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Steinbach, J.H., Neurobiol. Dept., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States; Harris, A.J., Neurobiol. Dept., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States; Patrick, J., Neurobiol. Dept., Salk Inst., San Diego, Calif. 92112, United States; Schubert, D.; Heinemann, S.
Abstract: Nerve and muscle cells from clonal lines interact in vitro, resulting in the association on the muscle surface of an area of increased acetylcholine sensitivity with a site of nerve muscle contact. This localization of acetylcholine sensitivity on the muscle cell to a site of contact between nerve and muscle was found to occur when acetylcholine receptors on the muscle had been blocked with α neurotoxin. Localization was also found to occur when the nerve cell had been prevented from releasing acetylcholine. It is concluded that neither the presence of active acetylcholine receptors on the muscle, nor the release of acetylcholine from the nerve, was required for the events leading to the localization of acetylcholine sensitivity in vitro.

Authors: Schubert, D., Tarikas, H., Humphreys, S., Heinemann, S., Patrick, J.
Title: Protein synthesis and secretion in a myogenic cell line
Affiliations: The Salk Institute, Post Office Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, D., The Salk Institute, Post Office Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States; Tarikas, H., The Salk Institute, Post Office Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States; Humphreys, S., The Salk Institute, Post Office Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States; Heinemann, S., The Salk Institute, Post Office Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States; Patrick, J., The Salk Institute, Post Office Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States
Abstract: Myogenesis in a clonal myoblast cell line is accompanied by an increase in the specific activities of creatine phosphokinase and myokinase and in the rates of synthesis and accumulation of myosin heavy chain. Exponentially dividing myoblasts synthesize myosin heavy chain at a rate of about 1% of their rate of total protein synthesis; this rate increases 7-fold during the differentiation process. Both myoblasts and myotubes secrete a minimum of 12-soluble proteins. Although there is a quantitative change in the rates of appearance of five of these proteins during myogenesis, no qualitative changes in the profile of the secreted proteins are detected. Three of the secreted proteins share several properties of soluble collagen molecules. Basal laminae and polymerized collagen fibrils are associated with myotubes, but not with exponentially dividing myoblasts. © 1973.

Authors: Schubert, D., Humphreys, S., de Vitry, F., Jacob, F.
Title: Induced differentiation of a neuroblastoma
Affiliations: Service de Génétique Cellulaire, l'Institut Pasteur, du Collège de France, Paris, France; The Salk Institute for Biological Studies, Post Office Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, D., Service de Génétique Cellulaire, l'Institut Pasteur, du Collège de France, Paris, France, The Salk Institute for Biological Studies, Post Office Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States; Humphreys, S., Service de Génétique Cellulaire, l'Institut Pasteur, du Collège de France, Paris, France, The Salk Institute for Biological Studies, Post Office Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States; de Vitry, F., Service de Génétique Cellulaire, l'Institut Pasteur, du Collège de France, Paris, France, The Salk Institute for Biological Studies, Post Office Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States; Jacob, F., Service de Génétique Cellulaire, l'Institut Pasteur, du Collège de France, Paris, France, The Salk Institute for Biological Studies, Post Office Box 1809, San Diego, CA 92112, United States
Abstract: Neurite formation in a cloned tissue culture line of mouse neuroblastoma C1300 can be rapidly induced by plating cells in serum-free or conditioned media. This induced differentiation, defined here in terms of neurite formation and a change in macromolecular synthesis, is not initiated by the inhibition of cell division, but requires a strong interaction between the cell and the surface of the culture dish. This interaction is inhibited by several proteins and is enhanced by one or more dialyzable cell metabolites. Neurite formation is reversible, and microtubule formation in neurites is dependent on protein synthesis. © 1971.

Title: Anti-Nucleic acid specificities of mouse myeloma immunoglobulins
Affiliations: Salk Institute for Biological Studies, San Diego, CA

Abstract: Three mouse myeloma immunoglobulins were shown to have antibody specificities for DNA. Two of these proteins bound denatured DNA and RNA in preference to double stranded DNA; the third was unable to distinguish them. © 1970 Nature Publishing Group.

Authors: Schubert, D., Cohn, M.
Title: Immunoglobulin biosynthesis. V. Light chain assembly
Affiliations: The Salk Institute for Biological Studies San Diego, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, D., The Salk Institute for Biological Studies San Diego, CA, United States; Cohn, M., The Salk Institute for Biological Studies San Diego, CA, United States
Abstract: A protein one-half the size of and antigenically related to light chain was found in immunoglobulin and light chain producing myelomas. The kinetics of its turnover are not consistent with its being a degradation product of light chain. The possibility that this immunoglobulin fragment is a synthetic intermediate in light chain biosynthesis is analyzed and discussed in the context of other data on light chain biosynthesis. © 1969.

Authors: Schubert, D.
Title: Immunoglobulin biosynthesis. IV. Carbohydrate attachment to immunoglobulin subunits
Affiliations: The Salk Institute for Biological Studies San Diego, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, D., The Salk Institute for Biological Studies San Diego, CA, United States
Abstract: There are two forms of heavy chain in IgA and IgM immunoglobulin producing mouse myelomas. One form, which contains carbohydrate, was found both intra-cellularly and in secreted immunoglobulin, while the other, devoid of carbohydrate, was found exclusively inside the cell. Detectable carbohydrate was attached to heavy chains at least two minutes after their release from ribosomes; no carbohydrate was found on light chains. Similarly, no carbohydrate was detected on nascent ribosome-bound heavy chains. The role of carbohydrate is discussed with respect to the mechanism of immunoglobulin secretion. © 1970.

Authors: Schubert, D., Cohn, M.
Title: Immunoglobulin biosynthesis. III. Blocks in defective synthesis
Affiliations: The Salk Institute for Biological Studies San Diego, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, D., The Salk Institute for Biological Studies San Diego, CA, United States; Cohn, M., The Salk Institute for Biological Studies San Diego, CA, United States
Abstract: Mouse myeloma mutants derived from ADJPC5, MOPC104 and X5563 were compared with their wild types with respect to heavy and light chain synthesis and immunoglobulin assembly. It was shown that two mutants which secrete only light chain synthesize a heavy chain. There was a block in the dimerization of heavy and light chain which produces the LH intermediate in IgG and IgM immunoglobulin-producing plasma cell tumors. Neither heavy nor light chain synthesis was detected in the third mutant, which secreted no unique protein. Immunoglobulin biosynthesis, control, and secretion are discussed in relation to these mutants. © 1968.

Authors: Schubert, D., Munro, A., Ohno, S.
Title: Immunoglobulin biosynthesis. I. A myeloma variant secreting light chain only
Affiliations: The Salk Institute for Biological Studies San Diego, CA, United States; City of Hope Duarte, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, D., The Salk Institute for Biological Studies San Diego, CA, United States, City of Hope Duarte, CA, United States; Munro, A., The Salk Institute for Biological Studies San Diego, CA, United States, City of Hope Duarte, CA, United States; Ohno, S., The Salk Institute for Biological Studies San Diego, CA, United States, City of Hope Duarte, CA, United States
Abstract: A mutant mouse myeloma cell line was derived from ADJPC5, which secretes an IgG2a immunoglobulin. The variant had lost the ability to synthesize immunoglobulin, but continued to secrete light chain. This light chain, and the light chain from ADJPC5 immunoglobulin, were indistinguishable as defined by peptide mapping of the secreted serum, and urinary proteins. Karyotype analysis showed that the mutant was derived from one of the 14 stem-lines observed in the wildtype myeloma. There was no detectable internal immunoglobulin in the variant, ruling out a block in secretion. It was also shown that the differential rate of light chain secretion was identical in ADJPC5 and its derivative. © 1968.

Authors: Schubert, D., Horibata, K.
Title: Immunoglobulin biosynthesis. II. Four independently isolated myeloma variants
Affiliations: The Salk Institute for Biological Studies San Diego, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, D., The Salk Institute for Biological Studies San Diego, CA, United States; Horibata, K., The Salk Institute for Biological Studies San Diego, CA, United States
Abstract: Four variant mouse myelomas are described which have lost the ability to produce immunoglobulin. These cell lines were compared with the original immunoglobulin-producing lines with respect to their secreted proteins, karyotype, transplantation characteristics, and intracellular immunoglobulin. Karyotype and transplantation data argue in favor of the derivation of the variants from their respective immunoglobulin-producing lines. One variant, that of MOPC104, secreted a light chain which was indistinguishable from the light chain of the wildtype immunoglobulin; the other three variant lines secreted no unique protein. None of the derivatives has demonstrable intracellular immunoglobulin, indicating that they are not blocked at the secretory step. © 1968.
